Description.val:
[P5 / 1V045 Access Systems & Subsystems]: Cryptologic Carry-On Equipment: The Cryptologic Carry-On Program (CCOP) procures state-of-the-art, commercial off-the-shelf signal acquisition equipment (hardware and software) in response to combatant commander requirements for a quick-reaction surface, subsurface, and airborne cryptologic carry-on capability. The equipment is procured according to the overall requirements detailed in the Shipboard Information Warfare / Cryptologic System Operational Requirements Document and specific execution year fleet requirements as defined by the Signals of Interest (SOI) Integrated Product Team (IPT), in concert with Shipboard Signals Exploitation Space (SSES) programs to ensure synergy and seamless transition to permanently installed SSES systems. The IPT meets several times a year and determines which SOIs/Targets on the SOI list need to be addressed. Due to a continually changing threat environment, detailed requirements are dynamic and equipment procured varies each year by quantity and type. Equipment suites can be configured for many targets and tasking. Target specific subsystems can either operate as stand-alone within cryptologic spaces or as an add-on to existing equipment. Hardware procurement includes: receivers, recorders, tactical computers and related peripherals, antennas, electronic-warfare support measures systems, precision geolocation equipment, advanced signal and search equipment including spectrum analyzers and associated portable special intelligence communications equipment. CCOP equipment is installed as an augment to cryptologic capabilities on subsurface, surface, and air platforms. There are approximately 124 cryptologic capable surface ships and shore sites in the current Navy inventory. Each of these are potential users of this carry-on equipment, as are subsurface and air platforms. The temporary installation of equipment is coordinated through fleet electronic support personnel. A primary system in inventory is the Carry On Radio Spectrum Analysis & Intelligence Reporting (CORSAIR) system. Funds continue to procure CORSAIR core architecture system upgrades to provide additional affordable functionality to the combatant commands. Additional signal acquisition equipment to address specific combatant command requirements include such systems as Digital Receiver Technology (DRT), Hostile forces Integrated Targeting Service (HITS), Maritime Toxic Pen (MTP), TURBULENTWAVE / TURBULENTWIND / TURBULENTSAIL, BLUESTREAM servers, RED FALCON / VULCAN, STINGRAY, MUDCAT, Toxic Fog, Radio Frequency Distribution Unit (RFDU), TEAPARTY/TEALEAF, Generic Area Limitations Environment (GALE)-Lite, and OWN FORCE MONIOTRING equipment.  This line also supports the procurement of STALLION hardware for CCOP team training.

[P5 / Global Signal Analysis Laboratory (GSAL) NAVIFOR]: The Navy Global Signal Analysis Laboratory (GSAL) program, under project name CLASSIC SENSEI, provides for the timely analysis of data derived from maritime Information Warfare (IW) operations. GSAL support is conducted by Signals Analysis Laboratories (SAL) that are co-located with Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOC) and other Fleet concentrations areas to perform high priority theater-level analysis and processing. The GSAL program office equips the SAL's with advanced signals analysis capabilities in order to accomplish the in-depth signals analysis that is required to effectively address processing and exploitation requirements in support of both maritime tactical and national strategic IW objectives. Funding is required to sustain SAL operations and support required integration for security and new technology requirements to facilitate highly technical analysis in a highly diverse, constantly changing, and contested electromagnetic environment. Navy SALs are integral components of the Tech Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) Revitalization initiatives that provide a collaborative enterprise architecture. GSAL procurement funding facilitates the data handling subsystem accredited by National Security Agency (NSA). This architecture known as LABLINK provides advanced manipulation, forwarding, and exchanges of data while providing connectivity with collaborating military, national, and international partners throughout the intelligence community. GSAL laboratories are located at Navy Information Operations Command (NIOC) Hawaii (Pacific Technical Analysis Center (PTAC)), NIOC Ft Gordon, Georgia (Atlantic SAL), NIOC Whidbey Island (Whidbey SAL), NIOC Bahrain (Bahrain SAL), NCWDG Suitland MD (Research SAL), Naval Information Operations Detachment, (NIOD) Digby (United Kingdom SAL), Australian and New Zealand Army Corps, Canberra Australia (ANZACSAL) and NIOC Yokosuka, Japan (Japan SAL) and at the Naval Information Warfare Activity (NIWA).

[P5 / System Integration & Installation of Hardware (FIOC) NAVIFOR]: There are FIOCs co-located with National Security Agency (NSA) Cryptologic Centers supporting Navy Geographical Priorities while leveraging national capabilities.  Each are charged with providing regionally focused Information Operation (IO) and Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) support to Fleet Commanders.  FIOCs leverage NSA capabilities, analysis, and manpower in support of Fleet requirements.  Funds are required for purchasing and maintaining life cycle support for command and control systems connected to SCI networks at the FIOCs. Funds are also provided to develop and maintain a common baseline of analytical intelligence software tools supporting FIOC capability areas as defined in the FIOC operational strategy (OPSTRAT).

[P5 / EW Fleet Synthethic Trainer Consolidation]: The Department's Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) (SIGINT / C-ISR) initiative addresses the lack of realistic SIGINT / C-ISR during exercises supporting the Fleet Training Continuum (FTC). Addresses critical requirements for SIGINT and C-ISR in Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) required in preparing Intelligence personnel/teams for forward deployed operations. This effort provides the ability to exercise shipboard TS-SCI capabilities in an environment not subject to counter-detection. Improves staff operational planning and tactical decision making combined with improvements to overall Intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the Optimized-Fleet Response Plan (O-FRP). Supports assured Command/Control (C2) and Cyber Situational Awareness/Cyber Defense and Enhanced Naval Network Environment (NNE) Information Dominance Integrated Process Capabilities Lists (IPCLs). Builds upon GENSER NCTE (Navy Continuous Training Environment) to expand the existing General Services (GENSER) NCTE with above GENSER capabilities to include TS-SCI FST architecture/capabilities. Provides for architecture, capabilities and scenario build-out as well as required life-cycle management. This capability will enhance individual units and Strike Groups in exercising integrated kinetic and non-kinetic capabilities, to include operations/intelligence fusion required for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW).

[P5 / Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) SIGINT / C-ISR]: The Department's Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) Signals Intelligence / Counter - Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (SIGINT / C-ISR) initiative addresses the lack of realistic SIGINT / C-ISR during exercises supporting the Fleet Training Continuum (FTC). Addresses critical requirements for SIGINT and C-ISR in Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) required in preparing Intelligence personnel/teams for forward deployed operations.  This effort provides systems with the ability to exercise shipboard Top Secret-Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS-SCI) capabilities in an environment not subject to counter-detection. This improves staff operational planning and tactical decision making and overall Intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the Optimized - Fleet Response Plan (O-FRP). Supports Assured Command and Control (C2) and Cyber Situational Awareness/Cyber Defense and Enhanced Naval Network Environment (NNE) Information Dominance Integrated Prioritized Capabilities Lists (IPCLs).

This effort provides the capability to exercise shipboard Top Secret-Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS-SCI) capabilities by expanding upon General Service (GENSER) Navy Continuous Training Environment (NCTE) capabilities to add Above GENSER architecture/capabilities. Provides architecture, systems and required life cycle management to improve staff operational planning and tactical decision making, and overall intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the Optimized-Fleet Response Plan (O-FRP). This capability will enhance individual units and strike groups in exercising integrated kinetic and non-kinetic capabilities to include operations/intelligence fusion required for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Signals Intelligence (SIGINT), Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW), and cyberspace operations.

[P5 / Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) (SIGINT / C-ISR)]: This capability will enhance individual units and Strike Groups in exercising integrated kinetic and non-kinetic capabilities to include operations/intelligence fusion required for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Signals Intelligence (SIGINT), Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW), and cyberspace operations.  FY20 funds continues the work of Life Cycle Management (LCM) of TS/SCI NCTE nodes, procures portable embarkation kits (PEKs), and TS/SCI systems for permanent shipboard installations.  FY20 increase in shipboard installation quantity reflects installations for newly commissioned ships.

[P5 / Tier 1 TS/SCI NCTE & VOIP Procurement & Installation]: FY19 funding completed procurement and installation of the Tier 1 NCTE node. There is no node scheduled for procurement in FY20 however, the second NCTE node is programmed to be procured in FY21.

[P5 / Tier 1 Life Cycle Management (LCM)]: FY19 and FY20 fund life cycle technical refresh of various equipment to maintain operability of the Tier 1 node.

[P5 / SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Permanent Shipboard Installation]: This is a new Cost Element in FY20. Shipboard installations commence in FY20 with 17 permanent shipboard installations to provide capability for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Signals Intelligence (SIGINT), Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW), and cyberspace operations.

[P5 / SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Life Cycle Management (LCM)]: This is a new Cost Element in FY20. Provides life maintenance/technical refresh for previously installed shipboard systems.

[P5 / Fleet Training Wholeness (FTW)]: FY19 funds procurement of installation and support services for permanent shipboard equipment.  FY20 funds procurement of additional portable embarkation kits (PEKs) to support distributed training.

Justification.val:
FY20 funds will continue to satisfy signals exploitation capability gaps as determined by the Cryptologic Carry-on Program (CCOP) Signals of Interest (SOI) Integrated Product Team (IPT) and Fleet Signals Development Working Group (FSDWG) and provide supplemental capability to host Signals Intelligence systems. At this time the recommendations for procurements that are best suited to address identified gaps may include: Digital Receiver Technology (DRT), Hostile forces Integrated Targeting Service (HITS), Maritime Toxic Pen (MTP), TURBULENTWAVE / TURBULENTWIND / TURBULENTSAIL, BLUESTREAM servers, RED FALCON / VULCAN, STINGRAY, MUDCAT, Toxic Fog, Radio Frequency Distribution Unit (RFDU), TEAPARTY/TEALEAF, and Generic Area Limitations Environment (GALE)-Lite, BLACKBIRD AND QUICKSHOT, OWN FORCE MONITORING equipment, Carry On Radio Spectrum Analysis & Intelligence Reporting (CORSAIR), as well as Adaptive Mission Packages. This line supports the procurement of STALLION hardware for CCOP team training. 

FY20 funds will provide for the timely analysis of data derived from maritime mobile Information Warfare (IW) operations. Global Signals Analysis Laboratory (GSAL) support is conducted by Signals Analysis Laboratories (SAL) co-located with Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOC) at theater-level analysis and processing centers and by QuickLook/Nodes forward-based at fleet concentration areas. 

The Navy's Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) (SIGINT / C-ISR) initiative addresses the lack of realistic SIGINT / C-ISR during exercises supporting the Fleet Training Continuum (FTC). FY20 funds continues the work of Life Cycle Management (LCM) of TS/SCI NCTE nodes, procures portable embarkation kits (PEKs), and TS/SCI systems for permanent shipboard installations. Increase in shipboard installation quantity reflects installations on newly commissioned ships.

Remarks.val: [Hardware/Recurring] [P5 / Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) SIGINT/C-ISR]: Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) SIGINT/C-ISR:  In FY 18 and out, this will fund Life Cycle Management (LCM) of the TS/SCI NCTE node on the East Coast and 14 Portable Embarkation Kits (PEKs).

Name.@footnote: The funding decrease of $6.571M from FY19 to FY20 is a result of satisfying Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO), Joint Urgent Operational Needs (JUON), and SOUTHCOM ISR requirements by upgrading, procuring and fielding desired Red Falcon capability and satisfying other signals exploitation gaps and Signals of Interest (SOI) requirements through Quick Reaction Capability. In addition, quantity and unit cost of Cryptologic Carry-on Program (CCOP) systems and subsystems vary because procurements are in response to current Combatant Command fleet requirements as well as the Signals of Interest (SOI) and target threat list which is updated twice a year. CCOP system and subsystem unit costs range from $.050M to $.900M, with the exception of Maritime Toxic Pen (MTP) which is priced at $2.150M per system and USNS (United States Naval Ship) OCO platforms which are priced at $1.786 per system. The unit cost listed above represents the average price per system.

Cryptologic Carry-on Program (CCOP) equipment is procured according to the overall requirements detailed in the Shipboard Information Warfare/Cryptologic System Operational Requirements Document and specific execution year fleet requirements as defined by the Signals Of Interest (SOI) Integrated Product Team (IPT). Due to a continually changing threat environment, detailed requirements are dynamic, contract award timelines and equipment procured varies each year by quantity and type.

FiscalYear.@footnote: FY18-FY20 Vendors: BIT systems, TICOM, KAB, SRC

ProcQuantity.@footnote: OCO funds for Red Falcon, JUON and USNS Platforms.  USNS OCO funds for $9.5M BTR recieved Aug 2018.
OCO funds for SOUTHCOM ISR requirements and funds CCOP equipment to SOUTHCOM maritime assets.

Name.@footnote: Quantity reflects investment into LABLINK infrastructure supporting Signals Analysis Laboratories (SAL) co-located with Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOC) at theater-level analysis and processing centers at forward-based at fleet concentration areas.

Name.val: GDX6D - System Integration and Installation of Hardware
3.1.1) System Integration & Installation of Hardware (FIOC) NAVIFOR

Name.@footnote: Decrease in funding from FY19 to FY20 (FY20 funding is $0) is due to the procurement of the Tier 1 NCTE node being completed in FY19.  No funding required for FY20 however, funding will be required in FY21 for a programmed Tier 1 node plus 2 Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) systems (one for the Tier 1 node procured in FY18/19 and one for the Tier 1 node procured in FY21).
Name.val: 5.1.1) Tier 1 TS/SCI NCTE & VOIP Procurement & Installation

Name.@footnote: Slight funding decrease from FY19 to FY20 ($1,000) reflects slight fluctuations in equipment costs to provide life cycle technical refresh of various equipment to maintain operability of the Tier 1 NCTE node.
This is a new Cost Element for FY20. Provides equipment/systems for 17 permanent shipboard installations.  Funding will be required through the FYDP.
Name.val: 5.1.3) SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Permanent Shipboard Installation

Name.@footnote: This is a new Cost Element for FY20. Provides life cycle maintenance and support for shipboard installed equipment/systems. Funding will be required through the FYDP.
Name.val: 5.1.4) SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Life Cycle Management (LCM)

Name.@footnote: Decrease in funding from FY19 to FY20 is reflective of fluctuations in both the number of shipboard installations per year, the locations of those installations (i.e., decreased travel requirement), and the exact number of PEKs required each year.
